transcription.text:
Videosphere was a JVC CRT television that was shaped in the form of a space helmet. It was first introduced in 1970 and was sold up until the early-1980s. It was popular for its modern design; the alarm clock base was an option however most units have a plain base.

Videospheres were produced in large quantities in white, red, black and orange in the seventies with a grey colored model also released in the 1980s. The design of the videosphere is said to have been inspired by the film 2001: A Space Odyssey,[1] though the videosphere's shape in itself remains as one of the most iconic examples of the early 1970s design ethos.

The sci-fi look of the TV saw a red model appear as a background prop in the 1999 film The Matrix, though they have appeared in sci-fi films since the early 70s. Soylent Green had a red model on screen as a prop.The 1972 film Conquest of the Planet of the Apes, a black videosphere was shown with a color capable tube and a slot that allowed a cassette tape capable of playing video. Humorously, the color image on the videosphere goes from being rectangular in one scene to round in another scene.

JVC Videosphere / Made in Japan / (Yokohama) / Serial # 10600147
240 V / 50Hz / 12V / 11W (Australian AC power plug). Has plastic casing, control dials positioned at the back of object with an aerial and chain to hang unit.

Today’s videogames focus as much on emotion as they do action. Through evolving technical expertise and the power of narrative, character and story are now as vital to a memorable gaming experience as ammo clips and power-ups. This video interweaves scenes from AAA, indie games and everything in-between to explore the emotional impact of games, as well as the white-knuckle tension of battle, how time can be manipulated for dramatic effect and how artistic expressions like movement and dance are bringing a human element to gaming.

Play is an essential part of who we are as individuals and as a collective. Since videogames were first invented by scientists in laboratories, our relationship to play has come a long way. From arcades and the first home consoles to today’s blockbuster releases, mobile games and experimental indies, videogames have evolved dramatically and so have we. How we interpret and experience videogames, and the communities and cultures spawned from them, reveals much about how society has shifted in the past five decades.

transcription.text:
Serial number VGN7875-1
Originally property of Cinemedia

One of Thor: Ragnarok's most heartbreaking moments is also one of its most beautiful. Adelaide-based VFX company Rising Sun Pictures created the pivotal moment where Tessa Thompson's character recounts the fatal encounter between the Valkyrie warriors and the Asgardian Goddess of Death, Hela. The flashback happens in artful slow motion, with the carnage captured under glittering light thanks to an innovative lighting rig designed by Satellite Lab to create high-speed changes in lighting. Rising Sun Pictures also demonstrated their expertise in slow-motion VFX in X-Men: Days of Future Past.

In 2016 it seemed like Overwatch went from a game no one had heard of to a global pop culture phenomenon overnight. Yet it's success was about more than just the mechanics of an advanced first-person shooter. Light on narrative inside the game, players worldwide became invested in the colourful cast thanks to animated short films released as bonus content. From tragic backstories to star-crossed romances, the game's developer Blizzard Entertainment made sure their millions of users weren't just invested in playable avatars, they were invested in characters.

Growing up in a Catholic home, Patrick Clair was used to seeing religious iconography. Little did he know he would one day have the opportunity to merge and subvert it with his work at motion graphics studio Antibody, alongside Raoul Marks. Having redefined the art of opening credits during the peak TV era, American Gods (2017–present) saw the Antibody team mix religious and patriotic symbolism together for their most daring work yet as they brought the mythologies of Neil Gaiman's source material to life. No photography
